awd_titl_txt: Better Preparing STEM Undergraduates for Employment: An Interdisciplinary, Problem-based Approach for Teaching and Assessing Teamwork and Interpersonal Skills
awd_abstract_narration:
Ninety percent of employers identify teamwork and communications skills of new STEM hires as equally or more important than the technical skills science majors bring to their first job. Few STEM majors have room in their technically heavy course load to introduce these skills. To fill this gap, this project creates and assesses a new academic model that spans across a student's four-year education, introducing the concepts in general education courses and allowing for an enriched application, practice and evaluation of these skills in their science courses. Psychology, social science and communication courses introduce the theory, practice and self-assessment of skills required for good teamwork. Students enhance and reflect on their skills through team-based interdisciplinary research projects, both in science courses required for their majors and through independent research. The project further explores how this model can be transferred to other institutions through collaboration with external universities, national workshops and publication in peer-reviewed journals. With the integration of this new academic model, STEM students are more competitive and better prepared for the interdisciplinary collaborations in high demand in the workforce of the future.

The project builds a university-wide model that provides comprehensive training, practice and evaluation of lifelong interprofessional skills to address this gap in the STEM workforce.  To meet this need, the project team transforms STEM education by creating a new four-year university-wide curricular model, including an Effective Teamwork and Communications minor, allowing students to learn, apply, and reflect on their interprofessional skills. These critical skills, and the theories behind them, are taught and assessed throughout students' education, in multiple courses, both in and out of their majors. The model avoids adding coursework by utilizing liberal studies courses, taught by appropriate faculty experts, which explicitly link the discipline specific theories of interprofessional skills to their use in a student's scientific discipline. Through interdisciplinary research problems, embedded in in-major courses, STEM students engage in genuine teamwork, learning how to continually assess their individual contributions and the quality of team interactions, preparing them to transfer these skills to the STEM workforce.

inst.inst_name: Indiana University of Pennsylvania Research Institute

por.por_cntn:
Ninety percent of employers identify teamwork and communications skills of new STEM hires as equally or more important than the technical skills science majors bring to their first job. Few STEM majors have room in their technically heavy course load to introduce these skills. To fill this gap, this project created and assessed a new four-year academic model that utilized general education courses to introduce and train students in core teamwork skills and upper-level in-major courses for their application within the student's STEM discipline.

Thus, general education courses in Theater, Sociology, Communications, and Management were created or existing courses augmented to match teamwork skills to the course's foundational content (i.e. Theater - nonverbal communication, empathy, and collaboration; Sociology - Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) and conflict resolution; Communications - verbal communication and presentation skills; Management - leadership styles). The use of general education courses had the following three impacts on the academic model: 1) core teamwork skills are taught by appropriate faculty experts linking the skills to discipline specific theories of the general education courses; 2) the integration of teamwork skills into required general education coursework minimized the credit burden on the student and institution, and 3) in-major courses to maintained their technically rich content while fostering the use of the teamwork and communication skills in the student's STEM discipline.

Multiple existing upper-level, in-major, STEM courses were revised to include a cross-disciplinary project requiring different areas of expertise, like in industry, which necessitates team member dependency. Team member dependence was achieved through a "boundary of disciplinary knowledge" which is best described as an artificial, pedagogical mechanism where no single team member contains the information necessary to solve the cross-disciplinary project. This dependency required communication of knowledge or use of others' skills and abilities to complete the project. In this type of setting, information, data, and materials sharing only occurred when each member effectively used their individual team skills to foster effective teamwork and communication.

The result of this project produced an academic minor in Professional Teamwork and Leadership requiring 3-6 credits of a student's free electives allowing a student to earn their STEM degree and minor within the 120-credit graduation requirement. With the integration of this new academic model, STEM students are more competitive and better prepared for the interdisciplinary collaborations in high demand in the workforce of the future. Through interdisciplinary research problems, embedded in in-major courses, STEM students engaged in genuine teamwork, learning how to continually assess their individual contributions and the quality of team interactions, preparing them to transfer these skills to the STEM workforce.

A detailed description of the curricular model and academic minor can be found in "Integrating Professional Skills into Undergraduate Chemistry Curricula" (DOI: 10.1021/bk-2020-1365).
